concepts.interpretation: Applies only when entire leasehold and reversionary interests coincide in the same person; no merger where one joint lessee acquires only part of the lessor's interest, as the lease remains intact and integrity is not broken by inter se partitions among lessees or lessors.
concepts.unlisted_description: Legal principle whereby a lesser estate is extinguished upon merger into a greater estate held by the same person, applicable to leases where landlord and tenant interests fully coincide.

concepts.interpretation: Maintains the integrity of the lease despite inter se partitions among tenants, binding all co-tenants to covenants over the entire leasehold.
concepts.unlisted_description: Legal relationship in leaseholds ensuring joint liability of tenants to landlord for the whole demised premises.

concepts.interpretation: Several co-tenants under one lease constitute a single tenant vis-a-vis the landlord, liable jointly for the entire rent; inter se partitions do not sever the tenancy or alter this liability.
concepts.unlisted_description: Principle that multiple holders of a single leasehold interest form one tenancy towards the landlord, with unified obligations regardless of internal divisions.

issues.text: Whether there was scope for the application of the doctrine of merger to the facts disclosed by the plaintiffs in their plaint such that Bisheshwar Dayal Singh's mokarrari interest merged in his lakhraj interest

anchor.surface_text: It, however, seems to us that there was noscope for the application of the doctrine of merger to the facts disclosed by the plaintiffs in their plaint. If the lessor purchases the lessees interest, the lease nodoubt is extinguished as the same man cannot at the same time be both a landlord and a tenant, but there is noextinction of the lease if one of the several lessees purchases only a part of the lessors interest.

issues.text: Whether an inter se partition of the mokarrari interest amongst the mokarrari-dars could affect their liability qua the lessor or the integrity of the lease
Whether there is privity of estate between the tenant and the landlord in the whole of the leasehold binding co-tenants for covenants running with the land
Whether partition inter se among the owners of the lakhraj holding could affect the integrity of the lease
Whether the two partitions alleged by the plaintiffs in paragraphs 5 and 8 of the plaint were proved leading to merger

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal it was contended by the learned counsel for the appellants that the High Court had erroneously held that the two partitions set up by the plaintiffs in paragraphs 5 and 8 had not been proved. It was argued that the evidence on the record, both documentary and oral, fully established the fact of the two partitions

arguments.claim: The High Court erroneously held that the two partitions set up by the plaintiffs in paragraphs 5 and 8 had not been proved

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal it was contended by the learned counsel for the appellants that the High Court had erroneously held that the two partitions set up by the plaintiffs in paragraphs 5 and 8 had not been proved.

arguments.claim: Evidence on record fully established the fact of the two partitions

anchor.surface_text: It was argued that the evidence on the record, both documentary and oral, fully established the fact of the two partitions

arguments.claim: In view of the partitions, Bisheshwar Dayal Singh became separate owner of eight anna lakhraj interest and his mokarrari interest merged therein

anchor.surface_text: and that in view of these partitions it should have been held that Bisheshwar Dayal Singh became separate owner of eight anna lakhraj interest and in that interest his mokarrari interest of eight annas merged

arguments.court_reasoning: No scope for doctrine of merger as no coalescence of entire lessor and lessee interests; partitions do not affect lease integrity

arguments.claim: Under certificate sale, whole interest of Bisheshwar passed to purchaser; defendants first party entitled only to six anna rent

anchor.surface_text: and that under the certificate sale the whole of this interest passed on to the purchaser in execution and that being so, the defendants first party could only maintain a suit for recovery of rent from the raiyats to the extent of their six anna mokarrari interest.

arguments.court_reasoning: No merger occurred, so certificate sale only of lakhraj interest; lease intact

arguments.claim: Both partitions alleged in paragraphs 5 and 8 proved; mokarrari interest of Bisheshwar merged in lakhraj; purchaser at certificate sale acquired complete interest; defendants entitled only to six anna rent

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge held that both the partitions alleged by the plaintiffs in paragraphs 5 and 8 of their plaint were proved and that the mokarrari interest of Bisheshwar Dayal Singh merged in his lakhraj interest and that at the certificate sale the purchaser acquired his complete interest both lakhraj and mokarrari

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nas in the whole of the leasehold. He then purchased a six anna interest in the entire reversion in the year 1916 and another two anna interest in it

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court held neither partition proved; Supreme Court no scope for merger regardless

arguments.claim: Neither partition proved; mokarrari interest of eight annas could not merge in lakhraj interest of sixteen annas held jointly

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in appeal held that neither of the partitions alleged by the plaintiffs were proved and that the mokarrari interest of eight annas could not merge in the lakhrai interest of sixteen annas held jointly by Bisheshwar Dayal Singh with the Pathaks.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed no merger, but on doctrine application to facts, not joint holding size

arguments.claim: No scope for application of doctrine of merger to facts in plaint; lease extinguished only if lessor purchases full lessee interest, not if one lessee purchases part lessor interest

anchor.surface_text: It, however, seems to us that there was noscope for the application of the doctrine of merger to the facts disclosed by the plaintiffs in their plaint. If the lessor purchases the lessees interest, the lease nodoubt is extinguished as the same man cannot at the same time be both a landlord and a tenant, but there is noextinction of the lease if one of the several lessees purchases only a part of the lessors interest.

arguments.claim: Bisheshwar never owned entire lakhraj or entire mokarrari; no coalescence of lessor and lessee interests in whole estate

anchor.surface_text: In such a case the leasehold and the reversion cannot be said to coincide. It was the plaintiffs case that mauza Darha was orginally granted in mokarrari under a single contract of lease and it was by inheritance that the lessees interest devolved on three branches of the family, Bisheshwar Dayal Singh getting an interest of eight annas in the whole of the leasehold.

arguments.claim: Mere purchase by one joint mokarrari holder of lakhraj portions does not extinguish lease or break integrity
Inter se partition among mokarraridars does not affect liability for whole rent; several tenants constitute single tenant qua landlord
Precedent in White v. Tyndall: tenants in common covenant one rent, not separate
Privity of estate between tenant and landlord for whole leasehold; liable for all covenants running with land
Inter se partition does not affect lease integrity or create new lease contract
Partition inter se among lakhraj owners does not affect lease integrity without fresh contract
None of conditions for doctrine of merger made out by plaint allegations
Private partition between mokarraridars and partition between lakhraj proprietors led to merger of Bisheshwar's interests

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint, it was alleged that there was a private partition between the mokarraridars by virtue of which the lands of village Darha were divided between the three sets of mokarraridars... as a result of these partitions the mokarrari interest of the defendants second party merged in his lakhraj interest

arguments.court_reasoning: Partitions do not break lease integrity or cause merger without full coincidence

holdings.text: There was no scope for the application of the doctrine of merger to the facts disclosed by the plaintiffs in their plaint

anchor.surface_text: It, however, seems to us that there was noscope for the application of the doctrine of merger to the facts disclosed by the plaintiffs in their plaint. If the lessor purchases the lessees interest, the lease nodoubt is extinguished as the same man cannot at the same time be both a landlord and a tenant, but there is noextinction of the lease if one of the several lessees purchases only a part of the lessors interest. In such a case the leasehold and the reversion cannot be said to coincide.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Doctrine requires complete coincidence of entire leasehold and reversionary interests; partial acquisition by one co-lessee does not extinguish lease

holdings.text: The mokarrari interest of Bisheshwar Dayal Singh did not merge in his lakhraj interest
holdings.reasoning_summary: Bisheshwar never owned entire lakhraj or mokarrari interests; no full coalescence despite partial purchases

holdings.text: An inter se partition of the mokarrari interest amongst the mokarrari-dars could not affect their liability qua the lessor for the payment of the whole rent or the integrity of the lease
holdings.reasoning_summary: Co-tenants under single lease form single tenancy vis-a-vis landlord; internal partitions do not sever joint liability or lease integrity

holdings.text: There is a privity of the estate between the tenant and the landlord in the whole of the leasehold and he is liable for all the covenants running with the land
holdings.reasoning_summary: Privity ensures joint obligations over entire demised premises despite co-tenancy

holdings.text: The allegation of partition inter se among the several owners of the lakhraj holding could not in any way affect the integrity of the lease in the absence of an allegation of a fresh contract
holdings.reasoning_summary: Reversion remains unified absent new lease agreement with split owners

holdings.text: None of the conditions necessary for the application of the doctrine of merger can be said to have been made out by the allegations made in the plaint
holdings.reasoning_summary: Allegations fail to disclose full unity of possession and title required for merger

holdings.text: Mere purchase by Bisheshwar Dayal Singh of portions of the lakhraj interest could not bring about an extinction of the lease or break its integrity as he was only one of the several joint holders of the mokarrari interest
holdings.reasoning_summary: Partial interests held jointly prevent merger or lease extinction

anchor.surface_text: In the words of Lord Halsbury in White v. Tyndall 1 , the parties to whom a demise is made hold as tenants in companymon but what they companyenant to pay is one rent, number two rents and number each to pay half a rent but one rent. There is a privity of the estate between the tenant and the landlord in the whole of the leasehold and he is liable for all the companyenants running with the land. In law, therefore, an inter se partition of the mokarrari interest companyld number affect the integrity of the lease and it companyld number be said that Bisheshwar Dayal Singh under the alleged partition became a mokarraridar under another company- tract of lease.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this appeal can be disposed of on a short point without taking into consideration the respective contentions of the parties raised before us or urged in the two courts below. The plaintiffs case rests solely on the allegation of merger of the eight anna lakhraj interest of Bisheshwar Dayal Singh with his mokarrari interest to the same extent. It, however, seems to us that there was no scope for the application of the doctrine of merger to the facts disclosed by the plaintiffs in their plaint.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; no merger of mokarrari and lakhraj interests even on plaintiffs' own case as alleged in plaint; High Court decision affirmed
